articles.headline: Resilient Kyiv Patches Up After Attacks, but Some Things Can’t Be Fixed
articles.snippet: After a barrage of Russian missile and drone strikes on the Ukrainian capital, its residents show a resolve to clean up and press on.
articles.abstract: After a barrage of Russian missile and drone strikes on the Ukrainian capital, its residents show a resolve to clean up and press on.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian missile ripped a gaping hole into a major intersection in central Kyiv. But just a day later, dozens of road workers spread hot asphalt to patch over the spot. At a playground nearby, where a missile had struck a set of swings, children raced each other up and down the steep sides of the blast crater as they played in the sun.
articles.byline: By Megan Specia and Brendan Hoffman

articles.headline: Trump Hotels Charged Secret Service Exorbitant Rates, House Inquiry Finds
articles.snippet: Records obtained by the House Oversight Committee show the former president’s properties charged more than $1.4 million to agents protecting him and his family.
articles.abstract: Records obtained by the House Oversight Committee show the former president’s properties charged more than $1.4 million to agents protecting him and his family.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump Organization charged the Secret Service up to $1,185 per night for hotel rooms used by agents protecting former President Donald J. Trump and his family, according to documents released on Monday by the House Oversight Committee, forcing a federal agency to pay well above government rates.
articles.byline: By David A. Fahrenthold and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: How One of Switzerland’s Oldest Banks Became a Meme Stock
articles.snippet: The longstanding troubles of Credit Suisse recently grabbed the attention of amateur investors whose social media posts sparked fears that the bank was running out of money.
articles.abstract: The longstanding troubles of Credit Suisse recently grabbed the attention of amateur investors whose social media posts sparked fears that the bank was running out of money.
articles.byline: By Maureen Farrell, Emily Flitter and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: Drones Embody an Iran-Russia Alliance Built on Hostility to the U.S.
articles.snippet: Authoritarian regimes in Moscow and Tehran have in common international isolation, domestic crisis and conflict with the West.
articles.abstract: Authoritarian regimes in Moscow and Tehran have in common international isolation, domestic crisis and conflict with the West.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Iranian-made drones that Russia sent on Monday to divebomb Ukraine’s capital delivered the most emphatic proof yet that Tehran has become a rare, increasingly close ally to the Kremlin, offering both weapons and international support that Russia sorely lacks.

articles.headline: Voters See Democracy in Peril, but Saving It Isn’t a Priority
articles.snippet: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that other problems have seized voters’ focus — even as many do not trust this year’s election results and are open to anti-democratic candidates.
articles.abstract: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that other problems have seized voters’ focus — even as many do not trust this year’s election results and are open to anti-democratic candidates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Voters overwhelmingly believe American democracy is under threat, but seem remarkably apathetic about that danger, with few calling it the nation’s most pressing problem, according to a New York Times/Siena College poll.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti, Michael C. Bender, Ruth Igielnik and Kristen Bayrakdarian

articles.headline: What Does ‘Abortion’ Mean? Even the Word Itself Is Up for Debate.
articles.snippet: In medical terms, the definition is clear. But when disputes arise, opponents argue that not every termination is an abortion.
articles.abstract: In medical terms, the definition is clear. But when disputes arise, opponents argue that not every termination is an abortion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even after five decades of argument about abortion in the United States, the most contentious question newly at the forefront is a very basic one: What is abortion?

articles.headline: Italy’s Next Government Hinges on a Familiar Face: Silvio Berlusconi
articles.snippet: Giorgia Meloni’s likely turn as prime minister will depend on support from the billionaire media mogul. So may the health of Italian democracy.
articles.abstract: Giorgia Meloni’s likely turn as prime minister will depend on support from the billionaire media mogul. So may the health of Italian democracy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — During the final campaign rally for Italy’s right-wing coalition before it emerged victorious in Italy’s elections last month, the billionaire mogul Silvio Berlusconi, a smile frozen on his waxen face, stood center stage, propped up, quite literally, by his hard-right partners, Giorgia Meloni and Matteo Salvini, who waved Mr. Berlusconi’s hand above his head.

articles.headline: In the Netherlands, Balancing Energy Security Against Climate Concerns
articles.snippet: A central location and web of gas pipelines are helping boost gas imports in the country even as it tries to stick to its clean energy goals.
articles.abstract: A central location and web of gas pipelines are helping boost gas imports in the country even as it tries to stick to its clean energy goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two enormous vessels tethered to a pier in the Eemshaven harbor in the Netherlands form the centerpiece of this country’s riposte to Russia’s throttling energy supplies to Europe.
articles.byline: By Stanley Reed and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: China’s Economic Picture Grows Murkier in Xi’s ‘New Era’
articles.snippet: The delay in announcing routine growth data this week was only the latest example of how hard it has become to peer into China’s economy, the world’s second largest.
articles.abstract: The delay in announcing routine growth data this week was only the latest example of how hard it has become to peer into China’s economy, the world’s second largest.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past quarter-century, China was run by a well-oiled government bureaucracy that predictably focused on the economy as its top priority.

articles.headline: Amazon Labor Union Loses Election at Warehouse Near Albany
articles.snippet: By a 2-to-1 ratio, the group had its second defeat since a surprise victory in April on Staten Island.
articles.abstract: By a 2-to-1 ratio, the group had its second defeat since a surprise victory in April on Staten Island.
articles.lead_paragraph: Workers at an Amazon facility near Albany, N.Y., have voted decisively against being represented by the upstart Amazon Labor Union, denting efforts to expand unionization across the giant e-commerce company.
articles.byline: By Karen Weise and Noam Scheiber
